scenarioDescription:
The GJ 3293 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 3293 is a star with 0.42 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.4 times its radius. It is located 65.85 light years away from the solar system.

GJ 3293 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 3293 system


GJ 3293 b

GJ 3293 b was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2015-03, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.14 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 3293 b is 23.551 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 3293 b is 5.190 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 3293 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


GJ 3293 c

GJ 3293 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2015-03, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.36 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 3293 c is 21.102 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 3293 c is 4.870 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 3293 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


GJ 3293 d

GJ 3293 d was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2017-06, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.19 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 3293 d is 7.603 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 3293 d is 2.670 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 3293 d is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


GJ 3293 e

GJ 3293 e was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2017-06, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 3293 e is 3.282 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 3293 e is 1.630 that of Earth. At 3.282 Earth masses, GJ 3293 e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system GJ 3293, which contains 4 exoplanets and was discovered by the La Silla Observatory.
name: GJ 3293 - System With 4 Exolanets
